turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Amy, you remember the party invitations Edward, gave you to mail?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Yes, daddy.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Did you mail then?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Yes, I did.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Where did you mail them?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I'll show you.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Amy, not that old tree!

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Yes, daddy.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: But I told you about that so long ago; you couldn't have been more than three when I told you that tree was a magic mailbox.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I didn't forget.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: But, Amy, that was just a story; it wasn't real.  That tree's no mailbox.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Amy, make a wish.  Wish real hard, and then blow out the candles, and your wish will come true.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But wishes don't come true.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Certain wishes do.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But you told me in the garden-- that the wish about the tree couldn't come true.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: But this is different.  Go on blow,

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: What do you want. Amy?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I wanted to talk to you,  I wanted to tell you about the other children.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Can't you tell me later?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But I didn't play with them, Daddy.  They wouldn't play with me.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: What do you mean you didn't play with the other children?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: It was on account of the birthday party.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Because you didn't ask them?  I don't blame them for being angry. Why didn't you explain what happened?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: They ran away.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Why didn't you run after them?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I did.  I came to an old dark house, and a voice called to me -- a lovely, sweet voice ---

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Now Amy

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: It's true.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: And who did the voice belong to?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: It was just a voice.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Now look, this is the last time you come to me with any such stories Â— I'm sick of this sort of thing.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Daddy, it's true.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Let me be the judge of that.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: No, I didn't.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Voices from an old dark house!

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: I'm sorry. Daddy and Mommy are a little upset.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: You're upset about me -- I made you fight --I hate for you to fight.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: These are all from me.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: This one says, "To Mother from Amy."

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Just you wait!

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: And this one's for Mrs. Farren.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: She gave me a ring, so I'm giving her a ring. I paid twenty-five cents for it, too.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: This one hasn't got a name on it. Who's this one for, Amy?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Daddy!

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Yes, Amy?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Why, daddy, you know my friend too!

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Amy, answer me. Why did you call her your friend?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Because she is my friend.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: It isn't a secret. She plays with me. She plays with me in the garden all the time. Right out there in the garden, she does!

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: In the garden? Would she be there now?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: She's there whenever I call her!

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: She's there, just like I said she'd be.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Where, Amy? Where do you see her?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Don't you see her?...Right there, under the tree.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Amy, there's nothing there. There's no one at all in the garden.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But Irena is in the garden. She's right there, under the tree.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Listen, darling. I want you to look once more. Take as long as you want. Look very carefully, and then I want you to tell me that no one's there.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But...

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: I have eyes too, and I tell you no one's there. If you deny that, if you insist that this woman you call your friend is in the garden, then I'm afraid I shall have to punish you. Do you understand?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Yes, she was afraid. She said there was someone who wanted to kill me.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: But there's no one here, darling.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: She's upstairs.. .the lady who lives up there.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Daddy?

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Yes, darling.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Tell me tha real truth. You can see my friend, can't you?

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: What'd you get for Christmas?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I don't know yet.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: My goodness, don't you open your presents until Christmas morning?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: We open ours on Christmas Eve. That's considered proper.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Well, I guess we're not a very proper family.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: You called me by my name.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Irena. But who are you?

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: I'm your friend.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I've wanted a friend.

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: I've wanted a friend too. I've been lonely.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But where do you come from?

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: You wouldn't understand. I come from great darkness and deep peace

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But where is that?

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: I can not tell you.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Will you be friend for always?

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: For as long as you'll let me.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I shall want you for always.

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: For always, then. Only you must promise never to tell anyone about me

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Not even Daddy...or Mommy?

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: No. This must be a friendship that only we shall have... you and I... Amy and her friend.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Oh, I like the sound of that.., Amy and her friend... Amy and her friend.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: You'll always play with me?

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: Whenever you want.

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: Can't you get it, darling?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I'll just never learn arithmetic.

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: But you must!

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: The numbers simply don't mean anything

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: Oh yes they do.  Look.  One is like a tall princess.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: A princess?

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: Of course. And Two is the prince who kneels before her on one knee.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Yes, yes! I see Prince,

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: That's right!

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: This is more fun than just pretend.

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: Of course,

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: There's an oak leaf.  Add a maple.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: That one's an elm.

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: light shining) in her eyes) Throw sea weeds into the flames, and the fire turns blue!

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But we don't have any sea weed.

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: Pretend, darling.  It's All Soul's Eve.  Round about the fire we go...  Over the flames we leapt

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: No, I don't think that's very much fun. Let's play house instead.  You be the friend who comes to see me.  I'll show you my children.

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: Your children?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: My dolls. We can pretend.

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: All right, Amy.  Button your sweater, darling. It's turning cold.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Yes, winter's coming.  I don't like the winter,

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: Oh, but the winter's fun. There's the wind and the snow. You'll like the warm fire upon the hearth, and the long, long nights.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Merry Christmas, Irena.  I brought you a present.

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: Oh, thank you, Amy.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: You can open it now, I guess. Lois Huggins says that's proper,

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: Oh, how beautiful!

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: It reminded me of you, so I bought it. It cost me more than all the others.

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: I shall wear it in my hair!

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Oh, that is more beautiful than I ever imagined it!  I wish I could show you to mommy and daddy.  I wish you could enjoy Christmas with us.

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: You and I shall enjoy Christmas together. Shall I show you my Christmas gift to you?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Oh, please!

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Merry Christmas.

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: A merry Christmas to you, Amy.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: So beautiful, Irena. So beautiful.

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: You wanted to share this moment with me.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: It stands so still.

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: Because it knows it can move with the swiftness of strong wind.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I can sea its breath in the cold.

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: It's a warm breath -- warm and strong Â— warmed by the sunlight that shone on the deer's back in the hot summer; sweet with leaves and mosses.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: May I pet the deer?

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: It is wildness and freedom. No one can touch it.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I want to touch it.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: It's you...Irena...my friend!

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: Don't cry, Amy.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: She's dead! I know what it is now when people say somebody died. I know what they mean! And I'm afraid. She's dead; she's dead!

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: You mustn't be afraid.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But she's dead!

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: Amy, listen to me. Death isn't such a terrible thing.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Oh, it is, it is! Death's terrible.

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: But, Amy!  Amy...I'm dead.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: You?

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: Yes, Amy.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But why?

turns.speaker: IRENA
turns.text: Death's like life. Death's a part of life. It isn't frightening. It isn't the end of everything. It isn't quiet and nothingness. It's a part of all eternity.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Getting the yard all fixed up for your party, Amy. You'd better hurry and get yourself fixed up too.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Mommy's taking me upstairs to change my dress right away.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Look at my ring.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: That's a fine-looking ring.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: A lady threw it to me.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Most surely that was a nice lady to give a ring to a little girl.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: It's a pretty ring.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I wouldn't be surprised if it were a true wishing ring.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: A ring that I can wish on like I wished on the candles?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Maybe, if it's a real mourning ring like we have in Jamaica. All you got to do is turn it on your finger, close your eyes, and make a wish.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: the ring up to him) What's a mourning ring?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: They're given to the living in memory of the dead.  If this is a real one -- I can't be sure -- you can make a wish, and it will come true in the twinkling of an eye.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Well, if it's a real mourning ring,. I'm going to think hard for something I want more than anything else in the world before I wish.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: That's the clever way to do it.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Been crying? That won't please your Daddy. You'd bettor cheer yourself up.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I'm trying to.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Let me take another look at that ring.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I wasn't singing to myself.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Oh, I suppose it was to the wind you sang, or maybe to the sun, or the clouds, or maybe it was to the flowers in the garden.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Little miss, you're stopping me in my work.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But I want to talk to you. Mommy says for you to come up to the old house with me. I've got to take back this ring.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: You just wait until I finish here. I've got to dust these ships for your Dad.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Will you come soon?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Soon as I finish.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: You're going to be busy all day long, Edward.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I do suppose so. But if you were there yesterday, guess you can get there today.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: That means I can go alone?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: About time for you to come home, Amy.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But Mrs. Farren just started to tell me a story. Please.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Little miss, don't you never come here alone. You gave me a fright, you did.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But she's such a nice lady.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: But I don't want you coming here alone. You get me to go with you when you want to come here. You promise?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: There was a deer on the other side of the fence.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: It's a hard winter. All the animals are bold as brass, coming down into the streets for food. You'll see a lot of deer this winter.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Mustn't look, little miss. Mustn't look.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But I saw what it was. It's the little deer.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Bad luck to see death in the snow.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But what happened to the little deer?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Probably hit by a car. Hard to see things in the twilight.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Why is it just lying there? Why doesn't it get up?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Because it can't. It's dead.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But it was alive Â— it was fast and strong!

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: It got hit.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But where has it gone?  Where's all the strength and the quickness?

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: I've been watching you. You couldn't see me, but I could see you. It was like peeking through a slit in the curtain before the play began. You would be a very good audience. I can see that.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: If you were the lady who gave me a ring, my mother says I have to give it back to you.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: Return it to me? Indeed you may not. I gave it to you as a present.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But my mother says I mustn't accept gifts from strangers.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: Stranger? Julia Farren a stranger. Why I've played every theatre from Boston to San Francisco. I've been to London and Paris. Those days Â— those beautiful, shilling, golden days.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But I only came to give back the ring.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: The ring? We'll have no more nonsense about the ring.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: She's always spying on me. She creeps into the room. She lives upstairs, yet she's always watching me Â— always!

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Who is she?

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text:
That woman is an imposter, a liar, and a cheat. How do you like your tea? 
                                AMY Well... .sometimes I got a spoonful of tea in a cup of hot milk.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: There you are. Take some cake, why don't you?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: No, thank you.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: One little piece of cake won't hurt you. Go ahead, take one. It's full of fruit...citron, cherries and ginger. It'll make you dream. Yes, wonderful dreams.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I like stories.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: Then I'll tell you a story Â— a lovely story. Do you know the story of Rapunzel?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Mommy read it to ne.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: Do you know the story of "The Headless Horseman?"

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: The Headless Horseman --

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Why hasn't he got a head?

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: It was shot off long ago in the great battles that were fought here; with the British on one side and the Americans on the other.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: He'll let me stay, Mrs. Farren. He'll let me stay.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I brought you a present. Merry Christmas.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: A Christmas present. It's been so long since I've had a Christmas present.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: Don't you hear it?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Who's Herne the Huntsman?

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: Don't you read Shakespeare?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: And does he kill people?

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: No, not people -- just deer and game, but the people he catches can never be free again. They too must kill and kill, covering themselves with blood.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Hide me? Why?

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: My little girl said she'd kill you if you came to see me. I can't let you die. We'll have to hide you.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Hurry, hurry.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: Yes, yes -

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Hurry!

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: I can't do it! I can't do it!

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: My daughter, Barbara, died when she was six. That was long ago. You're only the woman who keeps care of me. I know you.

turns.speaker: BARBARA
turns.text: Look at me.

turns.speaker: BARBARA
turns.text: You didn't even open my present and I'm your daughter.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: My daughter died long ago.

turns.speaker: BARBARA
turns.text: I hate the storm. I hate it!

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: The storms have done everything they can to me, I don't hate them. I don't even hear the wind. It blows beyond me. It was on such a night as this that Barbara died.

turns.speaker: BARBARA
turns.text: But I am Barbara. I didn't die.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: My Barbara was killed. I killed her. Yes, it was my fault. Everyone told me not to drive from the theatre. There was a raging wind that night, and snow and ice. All was well until we got to the Sleepy Hollow bridge. Barbara was singing a little song and then ...I don't know how it happened ..when I awakened, they told me the car was overturned, and they wouldn't let me see Barbara. Barbara was dead.

turns.speaker: BARBARA
turns.text: Oh, doesn't that prove something to you? Doesn't it?

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: Anybody could know that song.

turns.speaker: BARBARA
turns.text: Look at me. Look at me, mother darling. Look into my eyes. What color eyes did Barbara have?

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: Gray. They were a lovely, lovely gray.

turns.speaker: BARBARA
turns.text: And my eyes...my eyes are gray. Look! You see!

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: Yes...yes, that's true.

turns.speaker: BARBARA
turns.text: And my hair...what color hair did Barbara have?

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: It was pale...a shadowed gold.

turns.speaker: BARBARA
turns.text: Mother! You called me by name!

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: Yes, Barbara... Barbara...

turns.speaker: BARBARA
turns.text: Promise me you won't forget tomorrow. You'll remember, won't you? You won't say that it was just a dream. Promise me.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: Yes. Yes, Barbara, I shan't forget.

turns.speaker: BARBARA
turns.text: There's another promise you must make me. That little girl who comes here...she mustn't ever come to see you again. Promise me you won't see her.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: I-shan't see her. No, Barbara, no.

turns.speaker: BARBARA
turns.text: If that child comes here...if I find her trying to steal your love from me...I'll kill her. Yes, I'll kill her:

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: I'll not see her, Barbara. I promise.

turns.speaker: BARBARA
turns.text: Good night, mother, good night.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: Good night...Barbara...

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: Let the child stay.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Now, I don't know Amy --

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: On the dark nights Â— on the stormy nights -- you can hear him. He passes like the wind; The flapping and fluttering of his great cloak beating like gaunt wings. The thunder of his horse's hooves is loud, loud and louder, beating hard, beating strong on the frozen ground as he comes riding, riding, riding.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Little miss, you can't stay here. You've got to come with me.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: ...At the hour of midnight, down the road that goes through Sleepy Hollow, across the bridge, he goes galloping, galloping, always searching, always seeking

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Come away, Amy.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: There's a present you haven't opened yet, ma'am.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: That's from her -- that woman.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: It's some animal hurt in the woods that made that sound.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: Wait a minute. Listen.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: What is it, ma'am?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: It's dark. We'd better be getting on. The family will be waiting.

turns.speaker: MRS. FARREN
turns.text: Such a brief visit, but dear child, it has made my Christmas very merry.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Everything all right down there at the school, Mr. Reed?

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Yes, everything's all right, Edward.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: When I first heard all that talk about you going down to the school to see the teacher I got really afeard.  I thought maybe you night call off this birthday party -- and me with the cake already in the oven.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: I imagine a child would have to commit murder or rob the Seventh National Bank of Tarrytown to be deprived of a birthday party.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: I thought we were going to save those leaves you were burning for the compost bin.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Got more leaf mold now than we'll ever need, Mr. Reed.  I thought I'd burn 'em up and get the yard clean.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: You won't have long to wait. In just a few minutes this house will be overflowing with boys and girls. Off with you now, Amy. Go out and watch from the gate for all the children who'll be coming.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Go on -- out with you.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Well, ma'am, the truth is, I gave them to Amy hersolf to post.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: And Amy mailed them?

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: She pleaded so to do it

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Amy looks happy Â— seems almost as if she were playing with another child; like somebody else were running with her and playing.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: I like to see her happy.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: So do I, Mr. Reed.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: I didn't even have to coax her tonight.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: That's because she made a promise, and she'a keeping it, aren't you, darling.  You saw the way she played this afternoon, Edward.

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Indeed I did. Up and down the garden she went, laughing and singing to herself.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: "To Daddy from Amy." Here's one for Miss Callahan. This one says, "To Edward from Amy.".

turns.speaker: EDWARD
turns.text: Good heavens! What could you be giving me. Little Miss?

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: I know it may seem stupid of me--but it isn't the slap I'm worried about -- it's the reason.

turns.speaker: MISS CALLAHAN
turns.text: Something to do with a butterfly-- they were quarreling about it.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: No. Amy slapped Donald because he had hurt the butterfly -- and it was her friend.

turns.speaker: MISS CALLAHAN
turns.text: Well, that seems a harmless fancy --

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: Amy has too many fancies -- too few friends. It worries me. It doesn't seem normal.

turns.speaker: MISS CALLAHAN
turns.text: You'd better hurry.  I've left Amy in the car and she's getting impatient.  She tells me there's something especially important about a sixth birthday.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: We'll see that she gets there in good time

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: She refuses to deny it. She continues to believe in her lies.

turns.speaker: MISS CALLAHAN
turns.text: But don't you see...it's just what I was about to say to Alice...Amy in her own mind may not be lying.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: But there was nothing, no one in the garden.

turns.speaker: MISS CALLAHAN
turns.text: She needed, a companion, so out of her own hunger she created one. In her mind her friend was in the garden. In her mind her friend never leaves her. Right this very minute I'm sure she's upstairs sobbing out her grief to a friend who exists only in her mind.

turns.speaker: OLIVER
turns.text: But we have. She's wanted for nothing.

turns.speaker: MISS CALLAHAN
turns.text: Perhaps she's wanted for understanding.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: It all starts with them going to the bathroom together.

turns.speaker: CARLTON
turns.text: That many women in one place -- nothing good can come from that.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Sorry about Frida. She's been friends with Jen forever.

turns.speaker: CARLTON
turns.text: What's with her? If they're not bleeding they're PMSing. If they're not PMSing, they're warning you about the impending doom. If you're lucky, you get a sane person one week a month. Then you gotta date three or four women just to get some normalcy in your life.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm lucky Jen's not like that.

turns.speaker: CARLTON
turns.text: I don't believe in PMS. Women made it up just so they can be bitchy.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: My brother has an answer to PMS. A-S-S: Abundant Sperm Syndrome. A man gets sperm build-up, and if his woman isn't givin' it to 'em, he's gotta get it elsewhere.

turns.speaker: CARLTON
turns.text: Yeah and when your woman says you're an ass, say yes, I have Abundant Sperm Syndrome.

turns.speaker: CARLTON
turns.text: Waiter! She needs more water.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Can we get some service here?

turns.speaker: CARLTON
turns.text: No way is that the same chick. The other one was a dog.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Jennifer gave her a make-over.

turns.speaker: CARLTON
turns.text: Looks like a helluva lot more than a make-over. Was there surgery involved?

turns.speaker: CARLTON
turns.text: Guess you like those Coyote Ugly steaks now, huh?

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: Sorry, don't mean to be wolfing down. I'm just starving.

turns.speaker: CARLTON
turns.text: Don't apologize. It's great to see a woman really enjoying her food. I hate it when I buy a woman dinner and she won't even touch it.

turns.speaker: CARLTON
turns.text: No one I've run into knows what "coyote ugly" means.

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: Maybe that bartender made it up. I mean I think coyotes are rather beautiful. Maybe "coyote ugly" is really a compliment. Like someone who's conventionally "ugly" but is really beautiful.

turns.speaker: CARLTON
turns.text: Yeah that's like a three bagger. Today a bag is also a condom, so now a three bagger can be a chick that's really hot. So hot you gotta put several condoms on to dull the senses.

turns.speaker: CARLTON
turns.text: Sorry I didn't recognize you earlier. You look so different.

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: I've changed a lot lately.

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: You shouldn't smoke. It'll kill you.

turns.speaker: CARLTON
turns.text: Yeah yeah I know. Smoking kills. I'll quit someday. Doesn't it seem like all the cool people smoke?

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CARLTON
turns.text: James Dean, Humphrey Bogart...

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: Yul Brynner. They're all dead.

turns.speaker: CARLTON
turns.text: Yeah but they looked cool...

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CARLTON
turns.text: Your lips look delicious.

turns.speaker: CARLTON
turns.text: Wow your body's really hot.

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: I've been working out.

turns.speaker: CARLTON
turns.text: I mean body temperature. Do you have a fever?

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: Never felt better.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: A bite... Where'd you get bitten?

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: At Victoria's Secret.

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: There was a sale.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: I mean where on your body?

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: Oh, on my wrist.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: A dog at Victoria's Secret?

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: No, it was another woman.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: How's the rest of your health?

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: Good. Except for PMS.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: PMS. What symptoms are you experiencing?

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: It's hard to describe. I get really bloated and irritable and emotional and depressed and...

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: That's just part of being a woman. Diet and exercise should help. Avoid salt, sugar, starches, caffeine, alcohol...

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: What else is there?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And keep a journal of your symptoms to make sure it's related to your period and not just in your head.

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: It's not just in my head.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: That bite healed up quickly. It's been about three weeks?

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: Nearly four.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: How have you been feeling?

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: Okay, but I'm worried about the next PMS bout. It's gotten worse. I'm not myself during it. I get bloated, irritable, my breasts get huge, my nails turn into claws, my teeth get sharper and I have more facial and body hair.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Sounds all stress related. Your teeth may feel sharper if you're grinding them at night. You don't seem hairy to me. Is that all?

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: I get crazy dreams and I black out.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Diet and exercise, that's all there is. I'm not a big proponent of the PMS craze, but there's a book my wife mentioned called "The PMS Diet," which may be helpful.

turns.speaker: FRIDA
turns.text: Does she have PMS?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Now it's menopause. She's always hot. I gotta wear a parka around the house cause she keeps it so cold. It's always something.
